question: To restore a bog after peat extraction, which vegetation introduction techniques are most effective at establishing Sphagnum moss cover?
answer: Evidence from action documents indicates: • Adding Sphagnum moss (fragments or beads) to the peat surface typically establishes Sphagnum within 1–4 growing seasons, with cover reported from negligible up to >90%, and controlled studies show higher Sphagnum cover in sown than unsown plots; at one of three sites Sphagnum only survived when plots were mulched (ID: 1821). • Spreading mixed vegetation that includes Sphagnum establishes Sphagnum within 1–6 growing seasons, with reported cover from <1% to 73%; controlled studies show higher Sphagnum cover in sown than unsown plots, and several studies report Sphagnum cover is very low (<1%) unless plots are mulched after spreading (ID: 1822). • The moss layer transfer technique led to restored areas having greater moss/bryophyte cover (including Sphagnum) than unrestored areas after 4–8 years, and vegetation became more similar to natural bogs (ID: 1804). • Applying organic mulch after planting can increase Sphagnum or total moss cover in some studies after 1–3 growing seasons, though other studies in degraded bogs found no effect on Sphagnum cover (ID: 1828).
